Timeline of BSO and BOSS at Columbia

BOSS was founded amid Universitywide protests and concerns over inequitable housing policies that Black Barnard students faced.

BSO held the first Black Convocation at Columbia for the class of 2027.

Columbia designated the first

brownstone as a residential building for Black students. Columbia was one

of three Ivy League institutions to not

have a residential space devoted entirely

to Black students prior to student

move-in for the fall semester.

BSO was founded amid mass campus protests against the Vietnam War and a planned

gymnasium in Morningside Park.

The Africana studies department was established at Barnard. Departmental recognition was a more than 20-year-long effort in collaboration with BOSS to create a site for the multidisciplinary study of African and Black diaspora.

BOBW changed its official name back to BOSS. The name change reflects Barnard’s greater conversations surrounding the meaning and identity of a women’s college.

Malcolm X Liberation Lounge was dedicated as an official space to Black students on Columbia’s campus.

2023

1992

2002

1968

1980

2020

2000

2010

2024

1970

1990

2008

1969

BOSS changed its name from the Barnard Organization of Soul Sisters to the Barnard Organization of Soul and Solidarity to promote a more gender-inclusive space for nonbinary and trans students at Barnard.

The Zora Neale Hurston Lounge in Reid Hall was dedicated as an official Black space at Barnard.

BSO put on the first annual Kwanza Ball to celebrate Black student life at the University.

1974

BOSS changed its name to Barnard’s Organization of Black Women (BOBW).

Source: BSO and BOSS

Graphic by Diya Nair

Timeline of BSO and BOSS at Columbia

BOSS was founded amid

Universitywide protests and

concerns over inequitable

housing policies that Black Barnard students faced.

 

BSO was founded amid mass campus protests against the Vietnam War and a planned

gymnasium in Morningside Park.

The Zora Neale Hurston Lounge in Reid Hall was dedicated as an official Black space at Barnard.

1968

1969

1970

Malcolm X Liberation Lounge was dedicated as an official space to Black students on Columbia’s campus.

BOSS changed its name to Barnard’s Organization of Black Women (BOBW).

1974

1980

1990

The Africana studies department was established at Barnard. Departmental recognition was a more than 20-year-long effort in collaboration with BOSS to create a site for the multidisciplinary study of African and Black diaspora.

1992

BOBW changed its official name back to BOSS. The name change reflects Barnard’s greater conversations surrounding the meaning and identity of a women’s college.

2000

2002

BSO put on the first annual Kwanza Ball to celebrate Black student life at the University.

2008

2010

BSO held the first Black Convocation at Columbia for the class of 2027.

BOSS changed its name from the Barnard Organization of Soul Sisters to the Barnard Organization of Soul and Solidarity to promote a more gender-inclusive space for

nonbinary and trans students at Barnard.

 

Columbia designated the first brownstone as a residential building for Black students. Columbia was one of three Ivy League institutions to not have a residential space devoted entirely to Black students prior to student move-in for the fall semester.

Timeline of BSO and BOSS at Columbia

BOSS was founded amid Universitywide protests and concerns over inequitable housing policies that Black Barnard students faced.

BSO was founded amid mass campus protests against the Vietnam War and a planned

gymnasium in Morningside Park.

The Zora Neale Hurston Lounge in Reid Hall was dedicated as an official Black space at Barnard.

1968

1969

1970

Malcolm X Liberation Lounge was dedicated as an official space to Black students on Columbia’s campus.

BOSS changed its name to Barnard’s Organization of Black Women (BOBW).

1974

1980

The Africana studies department was established at Barnard.

Departmental

recognition was a more than 20-year-long effort in collaboration with BOSS to create a site for the

multidisciplinary study of African and Black diaspora.

1990

1992

conversations surrounding the meaning and identity of a women’s college.
